title: Matildas on track for a record Newcastle crowd against Korea on April 7 . | Port Macquarie News
body_text:
Newcastle is on track to host its biggest Matildas crowd when Australia play Korea Republic at McDonald Jones Stadium on April 7.

The city's record attendance for a Matildas match is 20,495, set against global powerhouse United States on November 30, 2021.
The Newcastle Herald understands ticket sales for the upcoming clash against Korea Republic were just shy of 21,000 on Monday, three weeks out from the international friendly.
Newcastle has long held an affinity with the "Tillies".
In 2017, before the nation got on the Matildas bandwagon, a then-record crowd of 16,829 turned out at Turton Road to watch on as Sam Kerr inspired Australia to a 3-2 victory against Brazil.
Newcastle knew a good thing when they saw it, well before attendance records were smashed across the country during and following the 2023 World Cup.
The Matildas' World Cup send-off match, played at Melbourne's Marvel Stadium on July 11, 2023, kickstarted a run of 16 consecutive sell-outs on home soil.
That incredible streak ended in Brisbane against Brazil in December last year.
The two games that followed against Taiwan at Melbourne's AAMI Park (December 4) and Geelong's GMHBA Stadium (December 6) were not sold out but attracted respective crowds of 26,795 and 30,000.
The April 7 clash in Newcastle against the Asian Cup silver medallists is part of a two-game series that includes a battle in Sydney on April 4.
It will be the first time the Matildas have played in Newcastle since a 3-0 shutdown of Jamaica in the Cup of Nations on February 22, 2023, when 9093 fans turned out at McDonald Jones Stadium.
The fixture kicks off a women's sporting fiesta for Novocastrians.
Rugby Australia will showcase the Wallaroos against New Zealand at McDonald Jones Stadium on May 10.
The women's State of Origin finale will be held in Newcastle on May 29, which will be followed by the inaugural NRLW Magic Round on August 2, where all 12 teams will play in Newcastle on one weekend.
A State of Origin women's record attendance of 25,782 braved cyclonic conditions as Queensland pipped NSW 11-10 in Game II of last year's series.
City of Newcastle announced last week it would update its Strategic Sports Plan due to a boom in women's sports participation, as well as predicted population growth.
Female football participation across the region and nation has exploded in recent years, and since the Matildas' World Cup success in 2023.
Northern NSW Football (NNSWF) chief executive Peter Haynes expected having the Matildas play in Newcastle would inspire more people to join the sport.
"It provides football in the Hunter with a great opportunity to continue to build on our growth, particularly in the female space," Haynes said of the Matildas coming to town.
"As of Monday, we had 14,122 female players registered for this season, which is a two per cent increase on last year, with female players making up 29 per cent of our total participation across northern NSW."
The boom in female participation across a range of sports has come with its challenges.
Facilities are one challenge.
NNSWF have appointed Gary Fisher in the newly created role of government relations manager.
Fisher said the role involved working with all levels of government to support clubs, predominantly at grassroots level, to provide improved experiences for all participants through investment in their facilities.
"Improving facilities across northern NSW is crucial to cater for the ongoing growth in our game, especially in the female space," Fisher said.
"We need to ensure that on the field and off the field participants, parents and supporters have a great experience at their club."
